critique: This document pertains to federal pay administration and establishes an advisory committee to advise the President on unresolved issues related to federal pay. It amends a previous executive order to designate the Secretary of Labor, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission as the President's Pay Agent. There is no indication of ideological bias, immigration stance, expansion of executive power, federalism implications, national security concerns, or social inclusion considerations. The document seems to focus on the process of federal pay administration and advice-giving.
